content: The "Antibullying Campaign Act of 2005" may be cited as such. Grants are provided for antiharassment programs. The Secretary of Education provides grants to States for antiharassment programs that prohibit harassment in schools based on various characteristics. States must submit detailed applications to receive grants. The Secretary of Education requires detailed applications from States for antiharassment programs, including information on prohibition of harassment, definitions, and budget. The Secretary reviews and approves or disapproves applications within 30 days. The Secretary of Education requires detailed applications from States for antiharassment programs, including information on prohibition of harassment, definitions, and budget. Approval or disapproval of the application must be done within 30 days. The State must contribute at least 50% of the grant amount from non-Federal sources for the antiharassment program. Approval or disapproval of the application must be done within 30 days. The State must contribute at least 50% of the grant amount from non-Federal sources for the antiharassment program. SEC. 3. STUDY AND REPORT. The Secretary of Education will conduct a study on harassment in public schools in the United States, focusing on the number of students harassed, demographics, types of harassment, states with anti-harassment campaigns, and state funding for anti-harassment programs. Privacy of students involved in reports of harassment will be protected during the study. The Secretary of Education will conduct a study on harassment in public schools, focusing on students involved in reports of harassment. A report containing findings and analysis will be submitted to Congress annually for 3 years. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "harassment" is defined as conduct that creates a hostile environment for a student's educational benefits or is threatening. "School" refers to an elementary or secondary school. "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "State" includes various regions like the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. The curr_chunk refers to territories and possessions of the United States, including the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Guam, and the Virgin Islands. Authorization of Appropriations: $75,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2006-2009, remaining available until September 30, 2009.
